description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4kblo","text":"We describe here a flexible protocol for eDNA metabarcoding with Oxford Nanopore's MinIon MK1C platform from sampling to sequencing. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8o8c0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"875f4","text":"The first section summarizes some key steps of sampling and sample preservation for both aquatic and terrestrial environments. The second one describes the DNA extraction protocol with the DNeasy PowerSoil Pro Kit of Qiagen for different types of samples (i.e., soil, liquid and dead plant materials). Our DNA amplification and bead purification protocols are characterized in the third section. Finally, the library prep with the Native amplicon Barcoding Kit 96 V14 (SQK-NBD114.96) and sequencing with the R10.4.1 flow cells (FLO-MIN114) and MinION Mk1C device are presented in the last sections. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ebkgl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8cho1","text":"This protocol has been optimized for protists (microbial eukaryotes) and 18S marker, but should be easily adjustable for other organisms, by modifying the sampling and DNA extraction sections, or other markers, even longer ones such as the full ribosomal operon, if need be.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dtueh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1enfj","text":"Our goal is to teach/train researchers from different fields and different expertise on obtaining nanopore sequences from environmental samples by guiding them from protocol to protocol, focusing on the key steps, and informing them of the expected results based on our 3 runs performed so far.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"h8e6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4q40i","text":"A comprehensive bioinformatic pipeline to treat the data produced, as well as a methodological article discussing this method and the best ways to use it are in preparation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"egmo3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edb79","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
disclaimer: {"blocks":[{"key":"d760p","text":"There are already a couple of metabarcoding protocols existing on this platform (e.g. Aquatic eDNA sampling and plant community metabarcoding with portable Nanopore Flongle sequencing (v0.0.3) V.3, Metabarcoding using MinION: PCR, Multiplexing and Library Preparation V.2, or Nanopore amplicon sequencing V.4 ) but because of the fast development of Nanopore technology, none of them used the most updated multiplex approach. In addition, some of them are too specific, and some focused only on sequencing, or library prep sections. Therefore, we estimated that this new exhaustive and global protocol was a valuable addition to this recent fast-evolving approach.\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":86,"length":110},{"key":1,"offset":198,"length":73},{"key":2,"offset":276,"length":32}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"9F12ED542D4D11EEB4F80A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.protocols.io/view/aquatic-edna-sampling-and-plant-community-metabarc-dm6gpr935vzp/v3"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"9F12EDA12D4D11EEB4F80A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.protocols.io/view/metabarcoding-using-minion-pcr-multiplexing-and-li-yxmvmxmxol3p/v2"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"9F12EDE32D4D11EEB4F80A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.protocols.io/view/nanopore-amplicon-sequencing-8epv5zrodv1b/v4"}}}}
keywords: eDNA Metabarcoding,Oxford Nanopore Technologies,Protists screening,Diversity survey,MinIon Mk1C,SQK-NBD114.96,DNA extraction,18S PCR,Bead Purification

steps.section: Sampling
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2779k","text":"Select a pristine area without anthropic disturbance and collect your sample of interest (e.g. ~  of soil, ~  of dry leaves or bark, ~  of water) in a clean plastic bag or bottle. Register all valuable sample information such as the date, label of the sample, localization of the site, coordinates, type of material, and name of the sampler, and label your samples accordingly. It is often recommended to take as well pictures of the habitat and the sample. Avoid as much as possible collecting stones, roots and animals as this will diminish the amount of DNA of interest. If you are worried about potential contamination during the sample collection you can use gloves. Moreover, sterilize your shovel, spoon, or any tool you use with ethanol or bleach to avoid cross-contamination between samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":96,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":108,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":134,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1ernc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"0.5-1","error":false,"guid":"38B5B5B010E211EE9929E9A134376136","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":7}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"50-200","error":false,"guid":"19B1093010E211EE9929E9A134376136","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":6}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"1-2","error":false,"guid":"276CD04010E211EE9929E9A134376136","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":3}}}}

steps.section: Sampling
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"37iv5","text":"As soon as your sample is collected it will be impacted by your storage condition, which matters a lot for microbial organisms, in particular, as they have a fast turnover. Consequently, you should avoid as much as possible to delay the return to the laboratory. In the meantime, you can use a cooler with ice or at least avoid storing your sample in a hot vehicle. Alternatively, aliquot ~  of nucleotide buffer, such as LifeGuard Soil Preservation Solution (Qiagen), in 5 ml tubes before starting the sampling, and place ~  of soil to stabilize it until the return to the lab.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":390,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":422,"length":45},{"key":2,"offset":524,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4g4n9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2-2.5","error":false,"guid":"5814691010E211EE9929E9A134376136","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C5D0FB3036B211EE9CCDCB478D4EF566","url":"https://www.qiagen.com/us/products/discovery-and-translational-research/sample-collection-stabilization/rna/powerprotect-dna-rna"}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"1","error":false,"guid":"607DE22010E211EE9929E9A134376136","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":6}}}}

steps.section: Sampling
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"b1ndg","text":"Once back in the laboratory, the best is to proceed to the DNA extraction as soon as possible. Until then, storage in the freezer ( ) is adequate for a few days for soils, but   is better for long-term storage. For aquatic samples, storing in the fridge overnight should have a low impact on microbial communities, but we do not recommend extending storage at   much longer. In addition, freezing aquatic samples is not recommended either as this could break cells during thawing and lead to DNA loss during further filtrations.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":131,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":176,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":360,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"621kb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"6819F91010E211EE9929E9A134376136","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-20","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"7330DEE010E211EE9929E9A134376136","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-80","unit":10}},"2":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}}}}

steps.section: Preparation of soils samples for DNA extraction
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"eauph","text":"Ideally, the DNA extraction should be performed under a laminar flow cabinet to avoid airborne contamination of the samples and reagents, this is particularly important when working with prokaryotes or fungi that are often dispersed in the air. Clean the cabinet with ethanol and install a microscale, a kit of DNeasy PowerSoil Pro (not open on the bench), a rack for 2 ml tubes size, a box of gloves, a bag of 5ml tubes, cleaning paper, a Bunsen burner, a lighter, a pen and a benchtop centrifuge machine. All reagents, boxes of gloves and tubes should not be open on the bench to avoid contamination! Once everything is prepared, sterilize well with the ethanol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":76,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Nanopore libraries planification
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"akc5","text":"In order to obtain the 200 fmol of DNA required for the library, it is necessary to calculate the mass it represents and this is directly related to the size of fragments obtained.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34gbv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4c3v7","text":"Some online calculators exist to help you, e.g. https://www.bioline.com/media/calculator/01_07.html","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":48,"length":51}],"data":{}},{"key":"5oj8u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4rgjr","text":"With our primers combination, we know that the size of our fragments should be around 1.8 kb, which is confirmed by the electrophoresis gels. But, because we know that some taxa possess up to 2 kb sequences and that we prefer to obtain rather a bit more than too little DNA at this step, we chose to target 2 kb instead of 1.8 kb. Based on the calculator, 200 fmol of dsDNA fragments correspond to a mass total of ~  . As the initial DNA samples required input is  , the concentration needed is therefore 260/11.5 = 22.6 ng/μl. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":415,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":464,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6i5qc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6nnrc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e56n1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3khiu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"A37EDE84129211EEA01B0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.bioline.com/media/calculator/01_07.html"}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"260","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":8}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"11.5","error":false,"guid":"BB0C7680129411EE9268A14D1F8F3191","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4gcmn","text":"It is possible to combine different projects with different sequence sizes and different sequencing depths (e.g. for barcoding). steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"b76cj","text":"Thaw the AMPure XP Beads (AXP), the EDTA and the Native Barcodes (NB01-96) at room temperature. The Native barcodes plate and the NEB Blunt/TA Ligase Master Mix have to be spun down and then mixed by performing several pipette mixes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d0nk3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Nanopore libraries planification
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"40qiu","text":"One of the great advantages of the Nanopore sequencing approach is its flexibility. Indeed, it is possible to sequence various samples with diverse fragment sizes simultaneously. In the present case, in addition to the 24 environmental samples, associated with the mock community and the two negative controls, we also added 9 samples of a single organism, with a different gene, with different sizes ranging from 630-750 bp. The results we obtained were adequate for all of them. steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8g88m","text":"ONT recommends to make up the library to 12 μl at 10-20 fmol. Too few fmol will leave the pores inactive which will reduce the yield of sequences but also damage the pores. Whereas, too much fmol will be detrimental as it could block the pores or perturbate the electrical signal. We always targeted just below 20 fmol. As   is the volume required for the loading step, we recommend preparing a higher volume of diluted library to compensate for the volume left during quantification(s) but also to be able to load several runs if required. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":323,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6e4u7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3bu2","text":"Similarly to the initial DNA input calculation for the library, we now have to calculate the mass of DNA to use for the loading step. Optionally, use the calculators if needed, e.g. https://www.bioline.com/media/calculator/01_07.html. Based on a fragment size of 2kb (we considered the ligated barcode and Nanopore adapters size as negligible) we then need to load less than 26 ng in the flow cell. As the loaded volume will be  , the concentration maximal needed is therefore 26/12 = 2.17 ng/μl, whereas the minimal concentration will be 1.1 ng/μl.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":182,"length":51},{"key":2,"offset":428,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e1t0m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b3je2","text":"Targeting a final volume of for instance  , the volume of diluted DNA will be: (Final Concentration (i.e. \u003c2.17) * Final Volume (i.e. 30)) / Measured concentration of diluted DNA. steps.section: Priming and loading the SpotON flow cell step, summary from the original protocol
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"aritl","text":"The activity of the pores should be extremely high in the first hours, but it starts to drop significantly and regularly after 1 day. ONT recommends pausing the run, washing the library, refueling the flow cell and loading a new library to maintain a high activity of the pores and optimize the sequences yield.  From our experience, we did not observe a significant improvement while doing so. We therefore suggest running the flow cell as long as possible until it dies, i.e., around 72 hours, before stopping the run.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
